author: kuzdogan
content: The EIP is merged: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7834 So we can also continue the discussion in the magicians forum

author: frangio_
content:
we're trying to decide what assembly code like `SWAPN 3` should mean. ie, what stack element does it swap?
it's a nuanced question so i've written down 3 alternatives here. please chime in!

https://hackmd.io/@frangio/Bk4Vjj6V1l

author: big_tech_sux
content: basically that it increases in-protocol complexity for no in-protocol benefit

author: big_tech_sux
content: <@425046919346257922> responded on the eth magicians thread

author: big_tech_sux
content: i actually think EXCHANGE is more important than DUPN or SWAPN; solidity didn't agree (due to language limitations of solidity they can't actually implement stack2mem) so we just added both

author: big_tech_sux
content: if you look at on-chain usages of contracts, higher numbered DUPs and SWAPs (like DUP15, SWAP16 etc) are very low in frequency

author: pdobacz
content:
Pasting my 2 cents on the topic from a related gh issue. Using the nomenclature from Frangio's hackmd:
> I personally prefer Exact on all 3 EIP-663 instructions, departing from both SWAPn/DUPn instructions (which, as I proposed in the other comment, can possibly be removed from the assembly language). To me SWAPn/DUPn were always confusing and inconsistent, to the point I don't really treat the "n"s there seriously. If you look at them in conjunction with PUSHn (and, taking the argument to the extreme - CREATEn, MSTOREn, LOGn), n is something else every time. We should detach from this convention when we have the chance.
> 
> I even prefer Verbatim over Traditional

author: _shemnon
content: Make the canonical name for 663 just SWAP and DUP then?

author: big_tech_sux
content: it reflects that the 13 is an immediate

author: funnygiulio
content:
<@273808422753796097> https://x.com/GiulioRebuffo/status/1868958524471992707

I am the guy from here - just wanted to say that the idea makes sense but it seems that adding solidity system contracts is a bit awkward + what about historical execution? i think that makes it harder for clients to handle both having to redirect to a precompile or to a sys evm contract based on the block number/hard fork.

author: funnygiulio
content: very unlikely any client will drop archive nodes btw

author: funnygiulio
content: I am just curious if there is any benefit to it
